title: Can Covid-19 change how Australians value the great outdoors?
description: Much of Australia has a climate that allows people to enjoy the outdoors most days of the year, but tough Covid-19 restrictions have limited the use of public space. Josephine Tovey looks at what’s changing in cities and considers how governments can make public spaces safely accessible for everyone
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Josephine Tovey; produced by Ellen Leabeater. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: How QAnon spread to Australia and spilled out into real life
description: In the second of a two-part special on QAnon, we look at how the baseless internet conspiracy theory spread to Australia, embroiling a Nationals MP from country Victoria who had to defend herself against a concerted campaign of vicious lies
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Michael McGowan. Produced by Cheyne Anderson , Joe Koning and Ellen Leabeater. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Full Story special: did anyone win the first US presidential debate?
description: It was tipped to be an explosive event and it didn’t disappoint. Jonathan Freedland and Guardian columnist Richard Wolffe discuss the highlights and lowlights of the first presidential election debate of 2020
contributors: Presented by Jonathan Freedland with Richard Wolffe; produced by Danielle Stephens

title: The dangerous global spread of the QAnon conspiracy theory
description: In the first of two episodes, Anushka Asthana and Julia Carrie Wong explore how QAnon has spread from the US to other parts of the world, including Australia, tracing its origins in a climate of deep uncertainty over the Covid pandemic and widespread social unrest
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana with Julia Carrie Wong, produced by Mythili Rao and Nicholas Cox. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard

title: How the death of Ruth Bader Ginsburg could change America
description: She was a pioneer of women’s rights and a liberal icon of the US supreme court. Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s death last week may alter the course of American politics and lead to a seismic shift towards a more conservative court for years to come
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reporded by Moira Donegan. Produced by Serena Barker-Singh and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson. Adapted by Gabrielle Jackson

title: Inside the rescue of the pilot whales stranded in Tasmania
description: A huge rescue effort kicked off when hundreds of pilot whales beached themselves in Macquarie Harbour off the west coast of Tasmania. Graham Readfearn explains how the rescue operation unfolded and reveals what a unique and intelligent species this is
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Graham Readfearn with Adam Morton. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: How does Australia balance its economic dependency on China with its democratic values?
description: Australia’s economy has benefited enormously from China’s extraordinary growth and the trade links have helped make Australia one of the world’s richest countries. But the relationship is increasingly strained. Daniel Hurst looks at the history of that relationship and what the options are for the future
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Daniel Hurst. Produced by Ellen Leabeater, Miles Herbert and Joe Koning. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Protecting history: how Juukan Gorge could change mining forever
description: When Rio Tinto destroyed a 46,000-year-old Indigenous heritage site, the world’s anger took the company by surprise. Now investors are demanding more transparency in how mining companies deal with traditional owners. Lorena Allam and Calla Wahlquist look at what’s changed since Rio blasted Juukan Gorge
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Lorena Allam and Calla Wahlquist. Produced by Ellen Leabeater, Miles Herbert and Joe Koning. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Donald Trump and a pattern of alleged sexual assault
description: In an exclusive interview with the Guardian, the former model Amy Dorris talked to Lucy Osborne about allegations that Donald Trump sexually assaulted her at the US Open tennis tournament more than two decades ago, in an alleged incident that left her feeling ‘sick’ and ‘violated’
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana with Lucy Osborne and Amy Dorris, produced by Joshua Kelly and Nicholas Cox; executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard

title: How Queensland's election became all about the premier and the pandemic
description: With just six weeks to go before Queensland voters head to the polls, it seems people can talk about little else than Covid-19. Annastacia Palaszczuk’s handling of the crisis has been well-received so far, but as Ben Smee explains, there are potential pitfalls in running a presidential-style campaign during a pandemic
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Ben Smee. Produced by Joe Koning and Ellen Leabeater. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: What does the poisoning of Alexei Navalny tell us about Vladimir Putin's Russia?
description: Luke Harding tells Anushka Asthana the alleged attack on Navalny has all the hallmarks of a state-sponsored hit. As Navalny appears to be recovering from the incident, western leaders are demanding answers from Russia
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana with Luke Harding; produced by Rachel Humphreys and Nicholas Cox; executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard; additional production by Joe Koning

title: Katharine Murphy and Adam Morton on the government's gas plan
description: Scott Morrison has been talking about the importance of gas in Australia’s energy market since the beginning of the year – but his speech this week raised more questions than it answered. Katharine Murphy and Adam Morton explain how we got here and what it means for the country’s climate commitments
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Katharine Murphy and Adam Morton. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Will social bubbles break the loneliness of living alone in Melbourne during lockdown?
description: After 10 weeks of various stages of lockdown in Melbourne, a new policy was announced to help single people who live alone, to allow them to spend time with others by forming a “social bubble”. While many people are excited about the prospect of being able to spend time with another person, others have questioned how practical some of the rules are.
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Josh Taylor. Produced by Joe Koning, Miles Herbert and Ellen Leabeater. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: The Austrian ski resort that became the centre of Europe’s Covid-19 outbreak
description: When Nigel Mallender headed to Ischgl from the UK in March, he was looking forward to a fun-packed break with friends. Just four days later, he and thousands of other tourists were desperately trying to leave after authorities became aware of coronavirus cases. Mallender and the Guardian’s Philip Oltermann discuss the fallout from that week
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys and reported by Philip Oltermann. Produced by Elizabeth Cassin and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are NNicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Additional production by Gabrielle Jackson

title: How Julie was forced to fight the system that was supposed to protect her
description: Neil Punchard is a police officer who leaked a domestic violence victim’s address to her violent ex-husband. The case shocked Australia and has campaigners asking why the officer is still employed by Queensland police. Ben Smee recalls all Julie has been through and raises questions the police force has yet to answer
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Ben Smee. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning with assistance from Miles Herbert. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Is democracy in America under threat?
description: As the US election draws closer, the Guardian’s Ed Pilkington hears from civil leaders on their fears for the integrity of the process and the future of their democracy
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana, reported by Ed Pilkington. Produced by Joshua Kelly and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard

title: What can we learn from Melbourne's stage-four lockdown?
description: The World Health Organization has called on governments to be clear about which Covid-19 restrictions are most effective to avoid blanket lockdowns in future outbreaks. With numbers now dropping in Melbourne and a roadmap announced, which measures have good evidence behind them and which don’t?
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Melissa Davey. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: David Marr speaks to Katharine Murphy about Scott Morrison and pandemic politics
description: Guardian Australia’s political editor Katharine Murphy has spent most of this year focusing on the Coalition’s response to the coronavirus and analysing what this tells us about how Scott Morrison governs. In this episode of Full Story, David Marr interviews her about the PM’s problem-solving approach and his dislike of tough questions
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and David Marr, reported by Katharine Murphy. Produced by Hannah Izzard and Miles Martignoni

title: Will Trump’s law and order gamble pay off?
description: The Guardian’s US Washington DC bureau chief, David Smith, discusses Donald Trump’s law and order gamble on the election, and how it is impacting on Democratic candidate Joe Biden’s campaign
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by David Smith. Produced by Mythili Rao and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard.  Adapted by Gabrielle Jackson

title: Australia's environment laws: are they about to get even weaker?
description: A recent review of the laws around Australia’s natural environment found they were failing. Now the government is hurrying to pass legislation that conservationists say could make them even weaker. Lisa Cox unpicks the debate and explains the consequences if the new bill is passed for Australia’s unique wildlife and habitat
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Lisa Cox. Produced by Ellen Leabeater with assistance from Jake Morcom  and Miles Herbert. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson
